author: By Dani Blum
title: Despite Encouraging Research, a Male Birth Control Pill Remains Elusive
description: A new study found that a birth control pill was 99 percent effective in preventing pregnancy in mice. But don’t expect a human version to hit the shelves any time soon.
content: A buzzy new animal study offers another contender in the search for a male form of birth control. Researchers at the University of Minnesota created a birth control pill for male mice, which proved 99 percent effective in preventing pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How effective are Covid antivirals?
description: Both Paxlovid and molnupiravir have been shown to reduce hospitalization and death from Covid-19 if taken early on in the course of an infection. “They are most effective when used within a few days of the onset of symptoms,” Dr. Gandhi said.
content: Both Paxlovid and molnupiravir have been shown to reduce hospitalization and death from Covid-19 if taken early on in the course of an infection. “They are most effective when used within a few days of the onset of symptoms,” Dr. Gandhi said.

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Recurring Floods, and Other Disasters, Take Their Toll
description: Besieged communities bond through adversity.
content: “We’re closed for the next few hours but the door is unlocked,” Darren Osmotherly said to rueful chuckles around his boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: mettlesome
description: This word has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word mettlesome has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 10 in “In Beijing, Britain’s Skeleton Team Resets, With Confidence” by Jonathan Abrams:

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: More sanctions on Russia.
content: After a day of intense global diplomacy in Brussels, President Biden said Russia should be removed from the Group of 20 nations. If the other member countries do not agree to the expulsion, he said, then Ukraine should be allowed to participate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: Did You Lose a Loved One to Covid?
description: Two years into the pandemic, almost one million Americans have died of Covid. Would you help us memorialize their passing?
content: The past two years have been traumatic and heartbreaking, especially for those who lost loved ones because of the pandemic. As the United States approaches the horrifying mark of 1 million deaths from Covid-19, we want to memorialize those who died, by remembering and sharing some of their final words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Judge Throws Out Maryland Congressional Map, in Blow to Democrats
description: The ruling, in which the judge said Democrats had drawn an “extreme gerrymander,” was the first time this redistricting cycle that the party’s legislators had a congressional map defeated in court.
content: A Maryland judge ruled on Friday that Democrats in the state had drawn an “extreme gerrymander” and threw out the state’s new congressional map, the first time this redistricting cycle that a Democratic-controlled legislature’s map has been rejected in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: For Taxes, Where You Hold Your Investments Really Matters
description: Retirement investments that are fine in tax-sheltered accounts can generate big headaches without that protection. Vanguard’s target date funds are a case in point.
content: Tax bills are bad enough when you know they are coming. When they are unexpected and large, and come from what seemed like a safe and reliable place, they are infuriating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel: Ted Cruz ‘Outslimed Himself’ This Week
description: Kimmel happily reported that the children’s book Cruz singled out to make a point about race at the Senate hearings for President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee this week became a No. 1 best seller.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Tariro Mzezewa and Jill Cowan
title: How Black Women Saw Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Confirmation Hearing
description: Watching the Supreme Court nominee was a major moment, but her treatment by Republican senators felt all too familiar. “Every Black woman speaks that language,” one woman said.
content: Jordan Simpson, a 25-year-old aspiring lawyer in Valdosta, Ga., was excited to watch the Senate confirmation hearing for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, until Senator Ted Cruz’s line of questioning made her feel something else: discouraged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: A Two-Ingredient Sauce for Pork Chops
description: Ali Slagle’s mixture of grainy mustard and fruit preserves is the ideal pairing for the seared chops.
content: Easy is the name of the game this week, as it’s still not quite feeling like spring — though we’re close — and Covid is still hanging on. But a few recipes are keeping me going and bringing some energy to my routine: Ali Slagle’s pork chops, coated in a sauce of mustard and jam, and Eric Kim’s gochugaru salmon, glazed with a mixture of red pepper, maple syrup, butter and rice vinegar. Also Naz Deravian’s sheveed polo — dill rice, from Iran — is a perfect teaser for spring, a gorgeously green moment that will resonate with dill lovers (me!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: Anna Sorokin Talks About Making Art
description: The group art show, “Free Anna Delvey,” is only the beginning for the imprisoned fake heiress.
content: Down a narrow hallway packed with lockers and plumes of marijuana and cigarette smoke, at A2Z Delancey, a small pop-up art gallery on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, some 150 unmasked art goers attended an opening last Thursday night for Anna Sorokin’s first group gallery exhibition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Utah Legislature Overrides Governor’s Veto of Transgender Athlete Bill
description: The measure bars transgender athletes from competing in girls’ sports. Lawmakers expect it to be challenged in courts.
content: The Utah State Legislature voted on Friday to override the governor’s veto and enacted a bill that would bar young transgender athletes from participating in girls’ sports, making the state the 12th in the country to enact such legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Like a Weapon’: Ukrainians Use Social Media to Stir Resistance
description: Photos and videos of the war’s horrors have spread quickly, searing into the global public consciousness and providing powerful ammunition in the information battle.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — A peace activist in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv rolled 109 baby strollers into a square last week to represent the children who had been killed in the war with Russia. Hours later, the image was available to millions on their phones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Messi, Ronaldo and Soccer’s Golden Sunset
description: This year’s World Cup will be the last for some household names, meaning soccer will go into the tournament with one elite and emerge with quite another.
content: In the heady, innocent days of 2016 — before all of the largely dreadful things that have happened since had happened — Nick Serpell was given what was, by the standards of the time, a faintly morbid task.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Elda Cantú
title: A New International Airport Is Not Quite Ready for Takeoff
description: Mexico’s president inaugurated the first of a series of long-promised infrastructure projects — possibly a little too soon.
content: MEXICO CITY — It is almost impossible to find water to drink throughout the entire, spanking new airport. The unfinished access roads still need signs, compelling confused drivers to reverse down the freeway. The only transnational flight scheduled for the foreseeable future is from Venezuela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Her Mother’s Roots
description: She ripped out the roses because they reminded her of her mother.
content: When Mary Pembleton first moved into her North Carolina home, she ripped out a rosebush with light-pink blooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: As Home Sale Prices Surge, a Tax Bill May Follow
description: Single sellers can exclude $250,000 from their taxable profit and married sellers $500,000. The amounts haven’t changed in 25 years.
content: It has been a seller’s market for houses in recent years, particularly in the pandemic. But bigger profits for homeowners may, in some cases, mean a large tax bill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Margaret Atwood
description: A conversation with the author Margaret Atwood.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Margaret Atwood. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Nebraska Congressman Faces Calls to Step Down After Convictions
description: Representative Jeff Fortenberry was accused of lying to F.B.I. agents investigating illegal foreign donations.
content: LOS ANGELES — A Nebraska congressman who was convicted Thursday on charges that he lied to federal authorities about having received an illegal campaign contribution from a foreign citizen is facing calls to resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Dzombak
title: Trilobite Fossils Suggest Cannibalism Is More Ancient Than Once Thought
description: The “king” of the trilobites was snacking on whatever it could eat some 514 million years ago in the Cambrian era, even shelled creatures of its own species.
content: Cannibalism is common among the millions of modern arthropod species. A praying mantis consumes her mate after copulation, termites suck blood out of wounded peers, and mosquitoes snack on larvae. But how far back does this gruesome mode of dining go in the history of life feeding on life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a poignant father-daughter yarn, a fairy tale that recalls the style of Guillermo Del Toro and more.
content: What if “Stranger than Fiction” was an action film? The absurd, melancholic happenings of the Chinese director Lu Yang’s “A Writer’s Odyssey” answers the question with feverish abandonment. It follows Guan Ning (Lei Jiayin), a former banker unmoored six years prior by the kidnapping of his daughter. All is lost until the tech giant Li Mu (Yu Hewei) sends his assistant to hire Ning. As it turns out, an online fantasy writer’s book about a young warrior destroying a mythic beast is magically killing the mogul. He wants Ning, endowed with the power to sling projectiles with deadly accuracy, to murder the writer, and in return, he’ll find this wanderer’s daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: British Museum to Remove Sackler Name From Its Walls
description: The decision comes just months after the Metropolitan Museum of Art said it would remove the family’s name from seven exhibition spaces.
content: LONDON — The British Museum here is to remove the name of the Sackler family from its walls, becoming the latest major cultural institution to cut ties with the family over its role in the opioid crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Soccer Mommy Stretches Her Sound, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Phife Dawg, Omar Apollo, Zola Jesus and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Need a Drink? Get in Line
description: Since mask restrictions were lifted, bar and club owners in New York City have reported huge crowds and long lines.
content: Want to grab drinks at a New York City bar these days? Expect long lines. Very long lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Miami Beach Bans Some Alcohol Sales as Spring Break Curfew Takes Effect
description: “We all knew that this week and next week were going to be hard weekends, because every year, they are hard weekends,” Mayor Dan Gelber said. “Frankly, optimism, hope and luck are not plans.”
content: Miami Beach is banning some nighttime alcohol sales in the city’s popular South Beach neighborhood for three straight nights, an emergency measure that went into effect on Thursday — the same day as a curfew intended to quell any spring break mayhem in the same area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: In a speech to the E.U., Zelensky singles out Hungary over sanctions.
description: Addressing the Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, directly, Volodymyr Zelensky said, “You have to decide for yourself who you are with.”
content: BRUSSELS — In another impassioned speech to European Union leaders, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called on Hungary to make clear whether it supported Russia or Ukraine in the growing battle over its neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Finucane and Olga Oliker
title: Zelensky Wants a No-Fly Zone. NATO is Right to Say No.
description: A no-fly zone in Ukraine, meant to protect civilians, might fail to do so while  escalating the war.
content: At the NATO summit this week, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine lamented what he viewed as the failure of the United States and its allies to help establish a “no-fly zone in any way” over his nation. This follows his earlier pleas for a no-fly zone imposed by NATO or the United States soon after Russia began bombarding Ukraine. The Biden administration and NATO leadership as a whole have continued to reject proposals to impose a no-fly zone over Ukraine. They are right to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Sarah Lawrence Cult Jury Hears From Key Witness: ‘I Became a Prostitute’
description: Claudia Drury offered an inside account of how, she said, Lawrence V. Ray controlled her and other college students.
content: In journals, emails and videos, Claudia Drury cataloged the transgressions Lawrence V. Ray convinced her she had committed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Hay House: How Designer Sheila Bridges Made Space for Herself
description: Sheila Bridges, known for creating Harlem Toile de Jouy wallpaper, talked to The New York Times about building her personal retreat from scratch.
content: For more than two decades, the interior designer Sheila Bridges, a creative beacon for Bill Clinton, Tom Clancy and Sean (Diddy) Combs, the hip-hop mogul currently known as Love, has divided her time between Harlem and the Hudson Valley. Most of those years, Ms. Bridges, 57, retreated to an antique farmhouse in the town of Germantown in Columbia County, where she kept horses, sheep, goats and chickens. But in 2019, she moved into a 1,600-square-foot village house near Hudson, N.Y., that was built for her from scratch. (Since 2015, she has also maintained a small residence in Reykjavik, Iceland.) Speaking from her weekend property, she talked about designing to please the ultimate client: herself. (This interview was edited for length and clarity.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: What Retirement Means for Your Taxes
description: Social Security benefits and your savings can be taxed. But in general, older Americans’ tax bills go down.
content: If you dread tax day every year, here’s a bit of good news: Your tax burden probably will lighten when you retire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ahmir Questlove Thompson
title: Questlove: Collecting Is an Act of Devotion, and Creation
description: A collection starts as a protest against the passage of time and ends as a celebration of it.
content: I have been collecting things for as long as I can remember. As a very young child, when I listened to music, read interviews or watched movies, they lingered in my memory, and I didn’t want them to leave me. Eventually, I got to thinking about the physical objects that brought me those experiences — vinyl records, print magazines. Collecting those items became a way to prevent the past from slipping away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Peter Bogdanovich Had a Vision for This Film. Now It’s Finally Being Seen.
description: “She’s Funny That Way” wasn’t exactly the movie he set out to make, but the director’s cut was feared lost. How it came to be shown at MoMA is a complicated saga.
content: Cash from a dentist’s office. Urns with ashes. A set of Chuck Close holograms. These are some of the items that Eric Eisenberg, 54, said he had found in storage lockers. A self-described “full-time eBayer,” Eisenberg makes a living buying lockers in arrears at auction and then selling the goods online. In one such purchase, he came across a  tape of a movie called “Squirrels to the Nuts” and added it to his eBay listings.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What are antiviral drugs and how do they work?
description: Antiviral medications have been around since the 1960s in the form of pills, intravenous solutions, ointments and even eye drops. They exist for only a handful of viruses, including H.I.V., the herpes simplex viruses, hepatitis B and C viruses, influenza A and B, and now the coronavirus.

title: Solo Climb
description: What story could this video tell?
content: German climber Jost Kobusch has been attempting to be the first person to scale Everest, the world’s tallest mountain, alone in winter, without supplemental oxygen.

title: Here’s the inside story of how New York City decided to end the vaccine mandate for pro athletes.
description: Less than two weeks ago, Mayor Eric Adams had a quick response to a heckler who implored him to drop the vaccine requirement that kept the Brooklyn Nets star Kyrie Irving from playing in New York City.
content: Less than two weeks ago, Mayor Eric Adams had a quick response to a heckler who implored him to drop the vaccine requirement that kept the Brooklyn Nets star Kyrie Irving from playing in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Scott Reyburn
title: Auction House Owned by Russians Tries to Distance Itself From War
description: With charitable donations and public statements in support of Ukraine, Phillips auction house is trying to deflect those pushing for a boycott of the business, owned by two wealthy Russians.
content: Russian troops had only started invading Ukraine when executives at Phillips auction house realized they had a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: What Is Driving Vladimir Putin?
description: Understanding Putin is crucial to deciphering his goals in attacking Ukraine. The Russian American journalist Masha Gessen recommends books on the Russian president and the forces that shaped him.
content: In an interview more than two decades ago, Vladimir V. Putin described his younger self, with a hint of self-congratulation, as “a hooligan.” When the interviewer asked if he was exaggerating about his tendency to get into brawls as a schoolboy, Putin took offense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘The Gains That Could Be Made Would Be Enormous’
description: Major League Baseball’s lockout suspended the league’s drug testing program. Doping experts say the opportunity was there for players to take advantage.
content: PHOENIX — When the 99-day work stoppage in Major League Baseball ended on March 10, the sport surged back to life. Delayed and truncated, spring training began within days. Free-agent signings and trades resumed almost instantly, and at a frenetic pace. Barred from team facilities during the lockout, players returned to clubhouses and fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Chambers
title: The Wallpaper That Is Also a ‘Reminder That My Ancestors Had My Back’
description: Sheila Bridges’s Harlem Toile de Jouy wallpaper and designs are getting even more attention. For this writer, it fills in the visual gaps of Black tradition.
content: I never had the slightest interest in wallpaper. Then Harlem Toile came along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Secrets of Lasting Friendships
description: Anthropologist Robin Dunbar provides a framework.
content: In early 2020, just before the start of the pandemic, I met a woman who said she practiced “aggressive friendship.” It takes a lot of her time, but she’s the person who regularly invites friends over to her house, who organizes events and outings with her friends. What a fantastic way to live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: ‘Can’t Cope’: Australia’s Great Barrier Reef Suffers 6th Mass Bleaching Event
description: This year offers a disturbing first: mass bleaching in a year of La Niña. The grim milestone points to the continued threat of climate change and greenhouse gas emissions.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — A wide stretch of the Great Barrier Reef has been hit by a sixth mass bleaching event, the marine park’s authority said on Friday, an alarming milestone for the coral wonder that points to the continued threat of climate change and greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Justice Clarence Thomas Discharged From Hospital, Court Says
description: The Supreme Court justice, 73, had been hospitalized for a week with flulike symptoms.
content: Justice Clarence Thomas, who had been hospitalized for the past week, was discharged Friday morning, the Supreme Court said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: The Monster That Followed Him Home From War
description: A disabled veteran takes his case to the Supreme Court.
content: ROBSTOWN, Texas — Le Roy Torres came home from his deployment in Iraq with a sickness he could neither explain nor shake: crushing headaches, fogs of vertigo, an increasingly harsh cough. Doctors shook their heads, prescribed ineffective antibiotics and, finally, to Mr. Torres’s deep mortification, suggested psychiatric medication.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who is eligible for antiviral pills?
description: Not everyone who tests positive for Covid-19 will get a prescription for antiviral pills, said Dr. Annie Luetkemeyer, a professor of infectious diseases at the University of California, San Francisco. To be eligible, you must test positive and have symptoms that started within five days or fewer. You must also be at increased risk of developing severe Covid-19.

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Yemeni Rebel Attack Sets Saudi Oil Facility Ablaze
description: Saudi officials accused Yemen’s Houthi rebels of launching the attack, which cast a shadow over a Formula One car race aimed at international spectators.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An attack on an oil storage facility in Saudi Arabia by Houthi rebels in Yemen on Friday ignited a huge fire that filled the sky over the port city of Jeddah with black smoke on the first day of a Formula One car race aimed at drawing international spectators.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Personal Tour of Modern Irish History
description: Fintan O’Toole talks about “We Don’t Know Ourselves,” and Julie Otsuka discusses “The Swimmers.”
content: Fintan O’Toole was born in Dublin in 1958, the same year that T.K. Whitaker, a member of the Irish government, published an influential report suggesting that Ireland open its doors economically and culturally to the rest of the world. O’Toole’s new book, “We Don’t Know Ourselves,” weaves memoir with history to tell the story of modern Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Sealing Their Relationship With a Pasta Stamp
description: Food helped bring Laura McDonald and Harsh Shah together. So it was only fitting for him to propose with a bowl of custom-designed corzetti.
content: While getting ready to meet Harsh Shah at Hoi Polloi Brewing, a taproom and lounge in Berkeley, Calif., on a November evening in 2019, Laura Min McDonald recalled wondering, “Do I even know how to go on a date?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Relocation of Presidential Office in Seoul Heightens Security Concerns
description: The South Korean president-elect’s decision to move both the presidential office and the Defense Ministry comes at a time when North Korea is rapidly escalating tension.
content: SEOUL — When North Korea on Thursday conducted a test of its most ​powerful intercontinental ballistic missile to date, South Korea’s Defense Ministry was busy with another urgent task: making plans to move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Navy SEALs in Vaccine Mandate Case
description: The justices blocked a ruling that would have prevented the Pentagon from taking into account whether service members with religious objections were vaccinated.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday restored the Navy’s ability to consider the vaccination status of 35 of its service members in decisions about where they should be assigned or deployed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Help’ Review: Blindfolds (and Kid Gloves) Off. Let’s Analyze Whiteness.
description: Claudia Rankine’s heady new play dares white audiences to deny the realities of their social advantages.
content: In July 2019, The New York Times Magazine published an essay by the poet and author Claudia Rankine titled, “I Wanted to Know What White Men Thought About Their Privilege. So I Asked.” A first-person investigation of white dominance and its broad range of social consequences, Rankine’s essay prompted more than 2,000 online comments, including many defensive replies from white readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Olivia Miles Is Shredding Defenses as a Freshman. How Far Can She Go?
description: The point guard became the first freshman — woman or man — to record a triple-double in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Now she has Notre Dame playing in the round of 16 on Saturday.
content: Olivia Miles doesn’t remember when she realized she was good at basketball. What she remembers is when other people realized she was good at basketball, which happened almost as soon as she started playing in fifth grade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: St. Peter’s: A Cinderella Story That Began in Jersey City
description: A tiny Jesuit college takes on Purdue tonight in the Sweet 16. It’s an underdog story that’s making New Jersey proud.
content: Good morning. We’ll look at St. Peter’s University and its improbable place in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament as the team prepares to face Purdue, the No. 3 seed, tonight. We’ll also look at how you will soon be able to call for an Uber and ride off in a yellow taxi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: ‘I’m Old, Not an Idiot.’ One Man’s Protest Gets Attention of Spanish Banks
description: A campaign by a 78-year-old retired doctor with Parkinson’s disease against banks closing branches and moving services online resonates with a rapidly aging Spanish population.
content: MADRID — Because he has Parkinson’s disease, and his shaking hands make it hard for him to push buttons, Carlos San Juan de Laorden, a retired Spanish doctor, finds it difficult to withdraw his money from the ATM.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament: Gonzaga Falls Short Again as the Favorite
description: Gonzaga, the No. 1 overall seed in the men’s tournament, will not return to the championship game after a loss to No. 4-seeded Arkansas. Arizona also lost, leaving Kansas as the only remaining No. 1 seed.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Top-ranked Gonzaga, which hoped to ride its high-flying offense to its first national championship, was stopped short of that goal with a 74-68 loss to No. 4-seeded Arkansas on Thursday night in a West regional semifinal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Ted Cruz’s Daughters Attend a Private School That Is ‘Antiracist’
description: The Texas senator aggressively questioned Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson this week for serving on the board of a school “overflowing with critical race theory.”
content: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas helped lead the Republican charge against antiracism efforts at a private school in Washington during the Supreme Court confirmation hearing this week for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson. But leaders at the private school in Houston where the senator sends his two daughters have articulated a similar commitment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Dagny Carlsson, Centenarian Blogger, Dies at 109
description: She began posting about her daily life in Sweden at the age of 99. She went on to acquire a worldwide fan base.
content: Dagny Carlsson, believed to be the world’s oldest blogger, who documented her life in Sweden and spread the message that age should not limit happiness, has died. She was 109.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: For U.S., Missed Chances Mean More Waiting
description: Fine margins are the hallmark of World Cup qualifying. For the Americans, their rivals and a handful of other teams around the world, Thursday was no different.
content: MEXICO CITY — As the final whistle blared late on Thursday night, Jordan Pefok fell to the grass and covered his face with his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Kip Hawley, Transportation Security Administrator, Dies at 68
description: He sought to overhaul a much-maligned federal agency by enhancing security procedures, bolstering morale and taking a common-sense approach to the job.
content: Kip Hawley, who after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, helped set up the Transportation Security Administration, and who became its fourth administrator after the much-maligned agency’s first three years of existence, died on Monday at his home in Pacific Grove, Calif. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Brooklyn
title: The Funniest Travel Account on Instagram Is Run by the T.S.A. Seriously.
description: Meet the woman behind the agency’s endless puns and dad jokes. (And don’t forget the 3.4 ounces rule.)
content: When the Transportation Security Administration comes to mind, it’s usually in relation to metal detectors, pat downs and being told that your bottle of sunscreen has to be trashed because it is larger than 3.4 ounces. Charged with, in its own words “protecting the nation’s transportation systems to ensure freedom of movement for people and commerce,” the agency’s officers screen millions of passengers each week and are not known for their sense of humor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: How the Owner of a Vietnamese Bakery Spends Her Sundays
description: Doris Ho-Kane honors Asian culture through her pastries and archival work. But on the weekend, she hits the playgrounds.
content: These days, Doris Ho-Kane is constantly filling cookie tins with confections featuring coconut pandan, black sesame ube and tamarind cacao nib. author: By Zoë Lescaze
title: How Should Art Reckon With Climate Change?
description: As the environmental crisis accelerates, contemporary artists have taken up the mantle of addressing the precarious present.
content: NOT LONG AFTER he joined the Princeton University Art Museum in 2006, the curator Karl Kusserow wore a bracelet bearing the phrase “Stop global warming” to a staff meeting. His colleagues noticed (“It was,” he conceded, “kind of ugly and noticeable”), but only a few of them knew it referred to a cause. The term was just getting mainstream traction — this was the year Al Gore released “An Inconvenient Truth” and Vanity Fair launched its first Green issue. But the science suggesting that industrial societies have thrown climatic rhythms wildly out of whack had been around for decades. Just a year earlier, the environmentalist Bill McKibben had railed against the culture’s perceived indifference. “Where are the books? The poems? The plays? The goddamn operas?” he wrote in an op-ed for Grist. “Compare it to, say, the horror of AIDS … which has produced a staggering outpouring of art that, in turn, has had real political effect.” For future generations looking back on the present, “the single most significant item will doubtless be the sudden spiking temperature. But they’ll have a hell of a time figuring out what it meant to us.”

Atwood — the author of the Booker Prize-winning novels “The Blind Assassin” and “The Testaments,” as well as “The Handmaid’s Tale,” “Oryx and Crake” and, most recently, the essay collection “Burning Questions” — was writing about these topics decades ago, forecasting the unsettling world that we inhabit now. content: Like so many first-generation Americans, the jewelry designer Monica Rich Kosann has always felt deeply connected to the past. Raised on Manhattan’s Upper East Side by an Austrian mother and a Hungarian father, she spent her childhood days wandering through museums and art galleries with her family. As a student at LaGuardia High School of Music and Art, Kosann would head downtown after class to rummage through antiques stores. At 16, the gift of a Rollei film camera from her father changed her life. Inspired by Alfred Stieglitz and Edward Steichen, she spent the next two decades taking portraits of friends and acquaintances. Her love of old, beautiful things never faded, and she amassed in that time “about a gazillion” Art Deco cigarette cases, powder compacts, Victorian lockets and minaudières from the early 1900s, which she acquired at the Marché aux Puces de Saint-Ouen in Paris, along Portobello Road in London and down Vienna’s cobblestone side streets. Kosann would insert her photos into what she called “image cases,” and give them as presents to friends, and by 2003, she launched her namesake line of sterling silver photo boxes. She eventually expanded into jewelry, offering oval filigree lockets, enamel vermeil zodiac charms and stackable gold bands that riff on 15th-century poesy rings.
